general_policies.title: Program Policies and Regulations
general_policies.summary: The Master of Data Science Policies and Regulations are part of the campus-wide UBC Policies and Regulations document. Below is a summary of those Policies and Regulations that students frequently ask about and that are specific to the Master of Data Science program.
general_policies.quote: The Master of Data Science Policies and Regulations are part of the campus-wide UBC Policies and Regulations document. Below is a summary of those Policies and Regulations that students frequently ask about and that are specific to the Master of Data Science program.

general_policies.title: Attendance
general_policies.summary: Attendance in lectures and lab sessions is expected. Your ability to succeed in the program depends on engaging fully with the material, your instructors, and your peers.
general_policies.quote: Attendance in lectures and lab sessions is expected. Your ability to succeed in the program depends on engaging fully with the material, your instructors, and your peers.

general_policies.title: Lecture recordings
general_policies.summary: We do not livestream or require instructors to record their lectures. If you miss a class you can catch up by reviewing lecture notes as well as by talking to peers and asking them to share their notes. When past lecture recordings are available, instructors may grant access to students who were absent for approved reasons only (e.g. illness, jury duty, etc.).

general_policies.title: Failed courses and C/C+ grades
general_policies.summary: To pass an MDS course a student must score 60% or above. To graduate from MDS, a student must pass all courses, with no more than 3 credits in the 60%-67% range (C or C+). All MDS courses are worth 1 UBC credit except for Capstone, which is worth 6 credits. Thus, to graduate from MDS a student can get no more than 3 C/C+ grades in Blocks 1-6 and must also score at least 68% in Capstone.

general_policies.title: Final course grades
general_policies.summary: With a few exceptions (communicated at the start of each course), grades are typically calculated as 50% labs and participation + 50% quizzes.
general_policies.quote: With a few exceptions (communicated at the start of each course), grades are typically calculated as 50% labs and participation + 50% quizzes.

general_policies.title: Late Submissions
general_policies.summary: A late submission is defined as any work submitted after the deadline. For a late submission, the student will receive a 75% scaling of their grade for the first occurrence, 50% scaling of their grade for the second to fifth occurrences, and will receive a grade of 0 for subsequent occurrences. Late submissions are cumulative throughout the program.

general_policies.title: Quiz Policies
general_policies.summary: Unless otherwise specified, MDS quizzes are **closed** book, with the allowance of a **single-sided**, **one-page**, **letter-sized** cheatsheet that is uploaded as a PNG to PrairieLearn before the quiz. Ensure that your cheatsheet complies with all stated requirements.

general_policies.title: Leaves of Absence (medical or personal)
general_policies.summary: Students in good academic standing may request long-term academic leave from the program for medical or personal reasons and return, within a year, to complete the MDS program. general_policies.title: Program Withdrawal
general_policies.summary: Students may withdraw from the MDS program for medical or personal reasons. Depending on the timing of the withdrawal, full or partial tuition fee refunds may or may not be given. A request to withdraw from the program must be submitted in writing to the MDS Leadership Team.

general_policies.title: Full-Time Commitment
general_policies.summary: The MDS program is approved by the UBC Senate as a full-time program. Hence, students must take the program on a full-time basis as part of their cohort and cannot complete the program on a part-time basis.
